brief_summary.textblock:
Some studies have revealed that an induced endometrial injury could improve embryo human
      implantation in patients with implantation failure.

      The purpose of this study is to determine whether the induced endometrial injury could be
      beneficial for regular patients undergoing IVF

clinical_study.brief_title: Embryo Implantation After Induced Endometrial Injury

detailed_description.textblock:
Endometrial induced injury has been suggested that could improve embryo implantation in
      cases of patients with recurrent implantation failure. The mechanisms that induce that
      improvement remain unknown.

      We want to analyse if the endometrial induce injury could be useful in cases of standard
      patients who require assisted reproductive techniques.

      For that purpose we will start a randomized controlled trial with the ideal background in
      implantation in ART, the egg donation programme.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  19-44 aged women

          -  19-28 Kg/m2.

          -  1st or 2nd fresh embryo transfer ( egg donation).

          -  1 or 2 blastocysts available.

          -  written agreement.

          -  > or = 6 mms endometrial thickness.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Premature ovarian failure.

          -  Endometrial pathology.

          -  Insufficient endometrial development.

          -  Hydrosalpinx

          -  Mullerian malformations.

clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Induced Endometrial Injury in the Subsequent IVF Cycle.

oversight_info.authority: Spain: Comité Ético de Investigación Clínica

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
